column1: Sandy Springs is a city in northern Fulton County
column2: Georgia
column3: United States. As of the 2010 census
column4: Sandy Springs had a population of 93
column7: 452. Sandy Springs is Georgia's seventh-largest city (just after Athens) and is the site of several corporate headquarters (though many are assigned "Atlanta" mailing addresses) such as UPS

column1: Human settlement in the area can be traced back to approximately 400 CE
column2: when Native Americans in the area forged three trails to better access the area's freshwater springs. During the 16th century
column3: the Creek Muskogee tribe settled the area
column4: where they remained until the early 1800s
column5: when they were forced out of the area due to the discovery of gold in it.In 1821
column6: the federal government held a number of land lotteries in the area
column7: resulting in the purchase of land in present-day Sandy Springs and subsequent settlement of the land. The Austin-Johnson House
column8: the oldest unaltered house in the town
column9: was built in 1842 on what is now Johnson Ferry Road. In 1851
column10: Wilson Spruill donated 5 acres (2.0 ha) of land for the founding of the Sandy Springs United Methodist Church
column11: near the natural spring for which the city is named. In 1905
column12: the Hammond School was built at Johnson Ferry Road and Mt. Vernon Highway
column13: across the street from the church.

column2: the state legislature blocked Atlanta from annexing the community
column3: which remained rural until the Interstate Highway System was authorized by the Federal-Aid Highway Act of 1956. In 1959
column4: after a fire at Hammond Elementary School
column7: urged residents to support annexation so that the area would have better firefighting protection. Community opposition killed the proposal. In the early 1960s
column9: connecting Sandy Springs to metro Atlanta and initiating a housing boom that brought new residents and major land development as part of the white flight from Atlanta after the Civil Rights Movement won greater racial integration within Atlanta. In 1965
column10: Hartsfield once again proposed the annexation of the Sandy Springs area. Spokesmen for Sandy Springs promised residents to "build up a city separate from Atlanta and your Negroes and forbid any Negroes to buy
column12: or live within our limits" should they reject annexation. In 1966
column13: annexation by Atlanta was defeated in a referendum

column1: Efforts to incorporate Sandy Springs began in 1966 in response to attempts by the city of Atlanta to annex this unincorporated area of north Fulton County. In the early 1970s
column2: the city of Atlanta attempted to use a state law to force annexation of Sandy Springs
column3: which failed after the Supreme Court of Georgia ruled that the law was unconstitutional. In response
column4: a group of residents formed the Committee for Sandy Springs 1975 to lobby for the incorporation of Sandy Springs. During this time
column5: proponents for an incorporated Sandy Springs argued that their taxes were disproportionately going to other
column7: communities in Fulton County. In every legislative session
column8: state legislators representing the area introduced a bill in the Georgia General Assembly to authorize a referendum on incorporation. Legislators representing Atlanta and southwestern Fulton County
column9: who feared that tax revenue would be lost from incorporation
column11: using the procedural requirement that all local legislation be approved first by a delegation of representatives from the affected area.In 1989
column12: a push was made for Sandy Springs to join neighboring Chattahoochee Plantation in Cobb County. This move was blocked by Speaker Tom Murphy.

column2: the Georgia state government determined that Sandy Springs
column3: along with other wealthier
column5: communities in Fulton County was being taxed below statewide minimums
column6: resulting in an increase in taxes for the area. Some Sandy Springs residents
column7: including Mitch Skandalakis
column8: launched a number of campaigns against the taxes
column9: and launched an unsuccessful lawsuit against the state.On January 16
column11: Eric Rudolph bombed an abortion clinic in Sandy Springs.

column1: When the Republican Party gained a majority in both houses of the Georgia General Assembly in 2005
column2: the procedural rules previously used to prevent a vote by the full chamber were changed so that the bill was handled as a state bill and not as a local bill. The assembly also repealed the requirement that new cities must be at least 3 miles (4.8 km) from existing cities that had stymied previous attempts to incorporate due to Sandy Springs directly bordering both Roswell and Atlanta. The bill allowing for a referendum on incorporation was introduced and passed as HB 37. The referendum initiative was approved by the Assembly and signed by Governor Sonny Perdue.

column1: Many residents expressed displeasure with county services
column2: claiming
column3: based upon financial information provided by the county
column4: that the county was redistributing revenues to fund services in less financially stable areas of the county
column6: and allowing excessive development. Many residents of unincorporated and less-developed south Fulton County strongly opposed incorporation
column7: fearing the loss of tax revenues which fund county services. County residents outside Sandy Springs were not allowed to vote on the matter. Efforts such as requesting the U.S. Justice Department to reject the plan were unsuccessful.The referendum was held on June 21
column9: and residents voted 94% in favor of incorporation. In November 2005
column10: voters returned to the polls to elect a mayor and six city council members. Eva Galambos
column11: who had initiated and led the charge for incorporation
column12: was elected mayor. Formal incorporation occurred on December 1
column13: making Sandy Springs the third-largest city ever to incorporate in the U.S. The city's police force and fire department began service in 2006.Upon incorporation
column14: Sandy Springs initiated a non-traditional approach by operating as a public-private partnership (PPP)
column15: with all but six full-time employees being contracted.

column2: the city undertook a procurement process to rebid all general city services
column3: which was won by CH2M Hill. The timing of this contract
column5: allowed the city to leverage a cheaper contract due to the economic downturn.In 2010
column6: the city became the first jurisdiction in Georgia to successfully "bail out" from the preclearance requirements of Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act.In 2019
column7: the Sandy Springs City Council moved to scale back the PPP model
column9: leaving only 15 outsourced full-time workers by the end of 2019. The city will still outsource a number of services
column12: street sweeping and ambulance services. The move is expected to save $2.7 million in the next year and more than $14 million over 5 years.

column1: The boundaries of Sandy Springs are Atlanta to the south
column2: Cobb County (at the Chattahoochee River) to the west and north
column3: Roswell (also at the river) to the north
column6: to the east.  A small panhandle in the northeast extends between the Chattahoochee River to the north and Dunwoody to the south
column7: ending in a very small border with Peachtree Corners in the extreme western edge of Gwinnett County.

column3: including Sandy Springs

column1: Riverside is the western district of the city

column2: or just "The Panhandle" is a residential area bounded by the Dunwoody city limit to the south
column3: the Chattahoochee River to the north
column5: and Peachtree Corners city limit to the east. The district's name is derived from the fact that it is wedged between the river and Dunwoody
column6: forming a geographic panhandle. Major roads include Dunwoody Club Drive and Spalding Drive
column7: and Interstate access is through the Northridge Road exit of Georgia 400. Many who lived in the neighborhood during Sandy Springs' incorporation considered themselves part of Dunwoody
column8: and voiced their opposition to the installment of street sign toppers labelled "Sandy Springs". Then-mayor Eva Galambos stated that these new signs would do nothing to diminish the neighborhood's identity.  Most residents now consider the area to be "Dunwoody in Sandy Springs"
column9: similar to the Buckhead Community district of Atlanta.

column1: Sandy Springs offers a host of annual events each year.
The Sandy Springs Festival is the largest community event in Sandy Springs
column2: with approximately 30
column3: 000 attendees. Established in 1984
column4: the annual festival celebrated its 30th year in 2015. The festival features a juried artist's market
column6: performances by regional acts and community bands
column7: a children's area with crafts and activities
column8: a teen territory with bungee jumps and inflatables
column10: the annual Doug Kessler Lighting 10K/5K race
column11: and a food court. The festival serves as the primary fundraiser for Heritage Sandy Springs
column12: a nonprofit dedicated to building community through preserving and promoting the historic and cultural identity of Sandy Springs. Heritage Sandy Springs also maintains Heritage Green
column13: a 4-acre (1.6 ha) park in the heart of Sandy Springs. The most recent festival was held September 19â20
column14: 2015. The next upcoming festival is Saturday September 22
column16: 2018.Sandy Springs Artapalooza is a free fine arts festival held each year in Sandy Springs. Each year 125 to 150 notable artists from across the country have the opportunity to participate. Organizers of the event include the Georgia Foundation for Public Spaces and ArtsSpring
column17: two groups that are dedicated to bringing free arts programs to the community.Stars and Stripes Celebration is an annual community fireworks display held over the July 4 holiday at the Concourse Corporate Center. The community gathers on the Concourse lawn for fireworks and live music.The annual Chattahoochee River Summer Splash
column19: is a 6-mile (10 km) float along the Chattahoochee River
column20: beginning at Morgan Falls Dam and finishing at Cochran Shoals-Powers Island National Recreation Area. After completing the float
column21: participants can enjoy an afternoon of live music
column22: food and fun during festivities at Powers Island. Guests can bring their own kayaks
column25: or rent them from several local outfitters.

column1: The Heritage Sandy Springs Museum opened on March 20
column2: 2010. It is dedicated to the history of the Sandy Springs community and is located in the repurposed Williams-Payne house at Heritage Green. Two notable exhibits are "Sandy Springs: Land and People"
column3: which tells the changing story of Sandy Springs as the home of Native Americans
column5: and modern suburbanites; and "A Land Nearby"
column6: which features a collection of 20 photographs of Georgia's Barrier Island taken by Dr. Curt Hames Jr.

column1: Sandy Springs also has a museum devoted to Anne Frank.
Sandy Springs' sixteen parks and greenspaces offer more than 950 acres (380 ha) of parkland.

Abernathy Greenway - The 6.6-acre linear park opened in 2014.  The playable art structures were created as part of an international competition developed by the Sandy Springs Conservancy and Art Sandy Springs and sponsored by Northside Hospital.

Heritage Green - a 4-acre (1.6 ha) park at the center of Sandy Springs' new downtown development. It is the site of the original underground springs for which the city is named and is anchored by the Heritage Sandy Springs Museum. It is operated and managed by Heritage Sandy Springs
column2: a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization dedicated to building community through preserving and promoting the historic and cultural identity of Sandy Springs. Heritage Sandy Springs presents a full calendar of public programs and events
column3: including the Sandy Springs Festival

Sandy Springs is notable for contracting private companies to perform the majority of its services in a public-private partnership model of government. While many governments contract with private-sector companies on a per-project basis
column2: Sandy Springs is believed to be the first American city to outsource its services for the majority of ongoing operations. The city regularly hosts delegations from other governments that are interested in the model. Services not outsourced include police
column3: fire-rescue

column1: The city's police department took over services from Fulton County on July 1
column3: with 86 police officers from all over the state of Georgia; it is now staffed by 137 officers. The city's fire department began operations in December 2006. The department consists of 97 full-time firefighters. The former police chief
column5: was replaced by Terry Sult in 2008 - 2013. Kenneth DeSimone was promoted to Chief in 2013.  The fire department was headed by Chief Jack McElfish from 2005 - 2014. The fire department is today headed by Chief Keith Sanders. It is staffed by 91 full-time firefighters and 52 part-time firefighters. The police department answered 98
column7: while the fire department handled 17

column1: The city of Sandy Springs has purchased the old Target Corporation building (originally Richway) located on the corner of Sandy Springs Circle and Johnson Ferry Road. In May 2018
column2: the new city hall opened after years of construction.Sandy Springs' model of public-private partnership has attracted considerable attention
column3: with city leaders from across the country and around the globe
column7: Finland and others visiting Sandy Springs to learn about their model. Since the incorporation of Sandy Springs
column8: several other municipalities in Georgia sought to replicate the city's style of governing
column10: many of these municipalities significantly altered their model since then.

column1: Roswell Road is considered the "main street" of the city
column2: with a majority of residents living within 2 miles of the corridor. It connects Roswell at the Chattahoochee River to the north into the Buckhead to the south. It runs through the heart of Downtown Sandy Springs
column3: with the City Springs complex being located on the highway.

column1: Recently completed major road projects include the widening of Abernathy Road between Johnson Ferry and Roswell Roads from two lanes to four plus a road median. The western intersection has been reconfigured so that traffic to and from Johnson Ferry Road â which carries heavy loads of Cobb County commuters across the Chattahoochee River at rush hour â now flows directly with Abernathy to and from the northwest. Additionally
column2: the Roswell Road bridge over I-285 has been widened to add a turn lane in each direction. There had previously been talk of a tunnel under the freeway to bypass the highway interchange altogether
column3: however this proved to be much too expensive. Another state project is the addition of a half-diamond interchange to Georgia 400 on the north side of Hammond Drive
column4: allowing southbound traffic to exit and northbound traffic to enter the highway.  (Ramps on the south side were not possible due to the proximity of the 400/285 interchange.)

column1: The city's public works department has made significant improvements in the conditions of roads and traffic signals since incorporation in December 2005. The department has cleaned approximately 1
column2: 500 catch basins
column3: striped 30 miles (48 km) of roadway
column6: re-timed hundreds of traffic lights to help improve the flow of traffic and reduce automobile idling
column7: and repaved 60 mi (97 km) of roads.

column1: The 2008 fiscal year saw the creation of the Sandy Springs Traffic Management Center (TMC). The TMC was constructed and began to operate in less than six months.  Construction began in February 2008
column2: five cameras viewed traffic along Roswell Road by the end of June.  Special features of the TMC include a webpage that allows the public access to real-time traffic conditions and voice-activated controls.  By June 2009
column3: 16 traffic cameras are now available and can be viewed online at the city's website.

column1: The major provider of mass transit is MARTA
column2: which operates a heavy rail rapid transit line and several bus lines through Sandy Springs. The city is served by the Medical Center
column3: Sandy Springs and North Springs stations. The Georgia Regional Transportation Authority also operates express buses from the North Springs station (which has its own ramps to and from 400) to other counties.

column1: Currently the city is limited in multi-use trails
column2: but bike lanes can be found in certain parts of the city. The city is currently working on creating more trails and bike lanes. Currently
column3: the Abernathy Greenway is a popular multi-use trail running adjacent to Abernathy Road
column4: connecting to Abernathy Park. The PATH400 Greenway Trail is a multi-use trail running along the Georgia 400 freeway in the Buckhead district of Atlanta. Sandy Springs is currently in the early stages of planning an extension of the trail through the city north into Roswell. Once complete
column5: it would run from the northern border of Sandy Springs to the Atlanta BeltLine.  As well
column6: the city is working with the Georgia Department of Transportation to transform the city's portion of Roswell Road into a more pedestrian and transit friendly corridor.

column1: The city has three consulates general.  The Consulate-General of Nigeria in Atlanta is located at 8060 Roswell Road. The Counsulate-General of India is at 5549 Glenridge Drive.
